  1. Dependable, close shave every time. Great price and great performance
  2. Shaves Very Nicely. Use it wet or dry. I especially like it wet, as close as a blade! Use it against direction of beard growth, and experiment with it. You will find that this shaver gives an EXCELLENT , QUICK shave! I recommend.<br /><br />Much Much better that the Braun electric it replaced! The Braun forces hairs through a small hole. Braun shaver is not as efficient as the Norelco, which uses a slotted head design. Closer shave & less irritation. I have given this much thought, and the Norelco is better!<br /><br />P.S. I do not have any affiliation with either company, I just have strong opinion that the Norelco is best.

  14. I've used several Norelco razors in my life and they have always served me well. This is an excellent product, very light-weight, quick charge and long lasting battery. Another winner from Norelco.
  15. I am happy with the Philips Norelco AT810 Powertouch Electric Razor. My last Norelco electric razor lasted me ten years ( it still works but the battery only stays charged for about two to three days nowadays, after a full charge.) This new razor works as well as my old one did, but I still have problems getting those pesky hairs under my chin. This razor shaves my cheeks and under my nose as well as a manual blade, though, but I still haven't found the perfect electric razor to shave under my chin as smooth as a blade. All in all, this is a very good razor, and the price was excellent on Amazon. My razor was delivered to my house less than a week after it ordered it (Amazon always has had fast delivery, at least for me).

  23. Gives a clean shave. Got this for my dad, actually, who is 85 and has a lot of wringles on this face and has fairly delicate skin (has had some skin cancer). It works just fine as far as removing wiskers. I think most of the hype about how close a shave a shaver gives is a little difficult to demonstrate objectively (an convincingly). A shave is a shave is a shave. Only people with too much money spend a $100 on a shaver.
  24. Ordered & it arrived the next day;<br /> charged for an hour (per instructions);<br /> operated/shaved smoothly, efficiently, quietly, & throughly on my &#34;medium tough&#34; beard/stubble;<br /> pop-up trimmer was precise and cut easily;<br /> stubble debris is directed away from the cutting heads preventing clogging and extra wear in the blades; and<br /> cleaned quickly, easily, & completely just running under very warm/somewhat hot water.<br /><br />I'm going to order a second one next month to have at work. This is the fourth Norelco razor I have owned in the last 30+ years. They improve their product every time. The folks at Norelco SCORE again!
  25. I bought this for my 18 yr old son - The Master of Disaster - for Christmas, and as of early June it remains fully functional. I gave it an extra star for that alone, as I find it quite remarkable.<br />Since my son literally used to drag a dry disposable razor over his face and then bang it on the sink (to clean it...) I can safely say this is an improvement. I do not hold this razor responsible for the quarter inch long spots of missed facial hair. Said son is not patient, and carefully shaving the ENTIRE face, even the bits he can't see, head on in the mirror, is time consuming and deemed feeble use of that time.<br />However, when my older, much more patient and thorough son appeared with about an eighth inch growth all over his face, after having used it, I became more skeptical. We later however, discussed the fact that it had almost certainly not been cleaned out in a few weeks... Still, ceteris paribus, I would probably recommend moving up to the 1150/x, unless you are buying this as a first razor for a teenager!
  26. Have used for a month. Seems to be working well. Was somewhat diappointed it didn't come with a stand. It would look less sloppy on sink.
  27. I bought this for my husband as Father's day gift. He's been waiting to have a electric shaver for so long and finally now he have one and he loves it!
  28. Delivers what it promises. However, it takes too long to finish an entire shave compared to a razor.   29. I am 73 and begin to have nicking problems with a razor as skin is getting thin. O have used this electric razor for 1 month with good results. The shave is not as close as a blade razor, but is adequate. I like it
  30. Very happy, no complaints. Quick charge feature is slick. I usually forget to charge my razor. Charges enough for a single shave in 5 minutes. This is about my 5th Norelco and my favorite yet.
  31. Replaces a 15 yr old Norelco - what a pleasure. And now I can shave wet or dry - though I am not sure of the advantage to wet.
  32. After experimenting with a non-rotary razor for two years, I decided to return to a rotary, and ordered this one. I am very pleased with it. It does a good job, is easy to handle, holds a charge for two weeks or longer, and is extremely quiet. I could not be more pleased.
  33. I used to have a Norelco razor but replaced it with another name brand and style in 2005. When that razor recently died, I decided to go back to a Norelco because I had fond memories of it. I especially like how long this one runs on a limited charge. Very handy! However, it does not shave as close as I would like. While my most recent shaver was a closer shave, I grew tired of the 'special solution' (read 'expensive') required to be used daily to clean it. The new Norelco is a snap to pop under the water to clean it up. So overall, the cost of ownership is much lower with this Norelco (vs. Braun), and I am OK with a 5 o'clock shadow.

I expect the ability to shave with shaving cream will also help in the summer when your face is sticky from the hot weather, because that makes shaving &#34;dry&#34; nearly impossible.
  45. I prefer blades to electric shavers, but there are times when a quick once-over with an electric just works out better. This model is a more recent version of a Noelco model I reviewed before. The shape and size are similar, but this one is a bit lighter, has a different color scheme, and is water resistant enough to be used in the shower. Now, I never shave in the shower, so I didn't test that part. The head style is a bit different on this model, but still cuts well. I got shaves as close as the previous model. The lighter weight didn't make much difference to me, and the ergonomic shape of both is very comfortable holding it in a variety of ways. Noelco really did their homework on ergonomics with this beastie. It feels good in one's hand and is easy to use. Unfortunately, they still include the pop-up trimmer, which I found poorly designed and virtually useless. Since the last time I tried it I gouged out a chunk of my beard in a dramatically unwanted fashion, I refuse to let it near my face again. It doesn't lock in the pop-up mode, and you have to be very careful how you use it. They should have improved it. Noelco's \\"floating head\\" design has always given better shaves than other electric razors, and this one is no exception. I have simply never seen any blade configuration that can beat the three circular heads which pivot independently for moving over the curves and bumps of one's face and head. It is the best of electrics. I have gotten very used to using the other model, and this one has taken its place for now. I still resort to blades whenever I want a really close shave or need to shape my beard, but these models are great for day to day touch ups or that quick \\"need to lose the scruffy look NOW\\" times. It could be a 4 with a decent pop up trimmer.
  46. Better than any other razor I've purchased thus far, but leaves behind stubble, no matter how much I attempt to shave it away. I was expecting this amount of money to leave my face baby butt smooth. :)<br /><br />But I would still recommend it. Great battery life. I can shave several days before having to put it on the charger.
  47. Update: 2013.04.06: Still working beautifully.<br /><br />Update: 2013.02.09: Still shaving just fine. The Philips Body Groom BG2020 and Panasonic Close Curves ES2216PC by this time were both barely shaving any hair by now and would even snag and painfully pull hair. Oh btw I'm using the Remington iLight Pro IPL6000 which has greatly diminished hair growth so I'm shaving less.<br /><br />Update 2012.10.19: I've noticed a just noticeable dulling since I bought it but not nearly as bad as the others I've had. Maybe my finer hair is more difficult to shave too. I'm still much happier with it than the others.<br /><br />Review: I bought this one exclusively for shaving my legs and body hair. I've used various different lady model electric shavers over the years for leg shaving and would ultimately be disappointed at some point with the head design, head's too small, quickly gets dull and leaves many hairs and stubble, or my favorite painfully starts pulling hairs. This Norelco is not marketed for women but why not? The head design has 3 contour following blades that make quick work of shaving the hair down smoother than any other model I've used. In fact I can shave my legs to where I don't feel any stubble.<br /><br />Notes: Norelco rotary shavers take a little getting used to and you may experience some \\"razor burn\\" until your skin gets used to it but it's worth it once you're past that if any Norelcos are a little more temperamental shaving right if they aren't kept clean. If too much hair stubble is allowed to collect the 3 cutters will get matting over with it and your shave will be very bad. So it's best to rinse it out under hot water before it gets to that point. Also if you use it on oily skin that oil will make it hard to rinse clean and you'll have to disassemble the head and brush the 3 cutters and combs clean frequently. Another thing is not to shave over long strands of hair or they may get pulled into the cutter and wrap around and clog things so that it doesn't shave very well until you pull the head apart and pick the hair out. You'll know if hair gets sucked into it because the sound of the shaver will change noticeably.<br /><br />One WARNING for newbies to Norelcos; DO NOT EVER mix up the head's 3 cutters and combs! Seriously don't do it! They are precision matched pairs and if you mix them up your shave will not be good! I know because I've done it. Given 2 weeks to a month of use they'll wear in and may shave pretty good again but given how pricey replacements are it's a mistake you just don't want to make! Most of the time to clean the head you rinse it in hot water. Only once every couple of months or more would you pull the cutters and combs out to clean or unclog them.<br /><br />I'm a long time senior electronics tech who appreciates a well fabricated device and I'm very mechanically inclined with precision machinery so I consider myself a good judge of the quality of electronic and mechanical devices.<br /><br />By the way I recently found my old silver computerized Norelco 5885XL from the mid 90's that has the big LCD that shows remaining shaves and notifies you when cleaning and maintenance is needed. I totally refurbished it, disassembling and cleaning the transmission parts, and soldering in new batteries. It looks and works like new now and shaves as good as my new Norelco.doesn't shave very well until you pull the head apart and pick the hair out. You'll know if hair gets sucked into it because the sound of the shaver will change noticeably.<br /><br />One WARNING for newbies to Norelcos; DO NOT EVER mix up the head's 3 cutters and combs! Seriously don't do it! They are precision matched pairs and if you mix them up your shave will not be good! I know because I've done it. Given 2 weeks to a month of use they'll wear in and may shave pretty good again but given how pricey replacements are it's a mistake you just don't want to make! Most of the time to clean the head you rinse it in hot water. Only once every couple of months or more would you pull the cutters and combs out to clean or unclog them.<br /><br />I'm a long time senior electronics tech who appreciates a well fabricated device and I'm very mechanically inclined with precision machinery so I consider myself a good judge of the quality of electronic and mechanical devices.<br /><br />By the way I recently found my old silver computerized Norelco 5885XL from the mid 90's that has the big LCD that shows remaining shaves and notifies you when cleaning and maintenance is needed. I totally refurbished it, disassembling and cleaning the transmission parts, and soldering in new batteries. It looks and works like new now and shaves as good as my new Norelco.

From what I have read though, and talking to my guy friends, this is normal. Using with water leaves my scalp baby butt smooth. Their is a shadow by the end of the day where I have normal hair growth but on my legs I get a smooth shave that lasts for days.   68. I replaced my nearly 30 year old Norelco with the AT810, and couldn't be happier. The new unit is lightweight, and quieter than my previous razor, but I have been really impressed with the battery life. I charged it up when I first got it, and after 6 weeks of daily use it finally flashed it's yellow light indicating time for a recharge. My old razor went for 3 weeks when new down to about 1 week when I replaced it's batteries (I had to replace it when the switch would sometimes not turn the razor off!)<br /><br />At first I was lamenting the lack of a battery status array of LEDs, but now that I've experienced the super long life, I just won't worry about it.<br /><br />Highly recommended.

  73. The AT810 from Norelco is a shaver from the company's early 2012 lineup. It comes in at a mid-level price point with good features, performance, and wet/dry flexibility. First, the charge on every Norelco product I have owned has been terrific. This AT810 is no exception. Indeed, it seems to be the best yet. You cannot use this product while physically plugged in, for safety, since they do not want to give anyone an idea to stupidly use it in the shower, plugged in. However, the lack of corded operation is NOT an issue because the battery life is phenomenal, potentially several weeks. Furthermore, in an event you do run out of power, a quick 1-2 minute charge will give you enough time to complete one shave. Second, the wet features is a terrific option and a feature that draws in customers Why not have this flexibility? Use it in the shower, with a foam or gel, or just with the water. Pick what you like. I prefer the dry operation, but I like the option! The shave is of good quality, but be sure to replace the heads at least once a year for optimum results. Many are knocking this 810 model as the entire head does not pivot. The next model up, 830, does pivot, but just slightly. I did not notice the lack of this feature at first, even though my 2.5 year old Norelco model does have the pivot feature. I have not noticed a difference in results with the loss of the pivot head. Therefore, I must assume that the slight pivoting head is more advantageous depending on the shape of your face. Lacking this feature, does not seem to change the results I get with the product. Your results may vary. Overall, a solid product. I would somewhat agree with reviewers who suggest that for the price, Norelco should have included the pivoting head on this model too. However, wet operation seems to be the draw factor by Norelco at this new, lower price point, and the pivot feature is reserved for the next model up. If you can get a good price on the 830, go with it, but you might try this 810. I have not had any issues with it. Good product.
  74. The last time I purchased an electric razor was in 2007. It was a Braun, and I paid roughly the same price as this Norelco AT810 costs. The Braun was a satisfactory product, but that's about it. It never got as close as a blade, especially on my neck. It required lots of hard pressing and reshaving. Worst of all, if my facial hair was anything more than 3 days' stubble, it hurt like heck to use. What a difference five years makes! This Norelco is a dream come true for a man like me who has very thick, coarse facial hair. PROS: -usable dry or in the shower -doesn't require the user to press hard, just gentle circular motions melt away the hair -doesn't hurt to use, no matter how long your facial hair -gets very close all over the face, and does well on the neck. I feel this will improve as my face/neck adapt to the electric razor. CONS: -cannot use while plugged in, presumably to avoid electrocution in the shower -not 100% great on the neck, could still require cleanup with a blade for the most formal situations Bottom line: a solid product, especially for guys like me with thick facial hair. I will not be going back to my old electric Braun.
  75. AS GREAT AS IS ASKED ... THANKS
  76. light weight. easy to clean. long lasting power reserve. shave well. all in all, this is a very good shaver for the price I paid.
  77. The razor is quick to charge up, easy to handle and quick to clean w/ water. Holds a charge for over a week with daily use. It really shaves close without irratation. Glad I got it for home and travel.

Never used it in the shower (Norelco says you can) but every few days I washed out any loose hair around the blades with running water. The part containing the blades opens for cleaning and I always left it open afterwards so the water could dry.
  80. The Philips-Norelco AT810 is a very similar to the Philips-Norelco 7310XL from a few years ago. The key differences being the way it fits in your hand, and the AT810 has different grates covering the blade. I would assume it is to tackle different types of hair easier. While the blades themselves bend in a bit to contour to your cheeks and/or chin, the AT810 has a fixed head and doesnt fare well around the neck. It does rather well on the face, especially with the use of Lectric Shave. It also comes with a beard trimmer, although as has been the case with the 7310XL, the AT810 beard trimmer leaves much to be desired as far as shaping your beard is concerned. So, you are the kind of guy who likes to have a clean shaven face -- this is the only tool you'll need (plus some Lectric Shave or similar product). However, if you maintain a beard or goatee, this will do great in the \\"field\\", but you'll still need a straight razor!
  81. My husband uses this electric razor almost everyday and he absolutely loves it! He hasn't had any issues with it and he has been using it for almost a year now.
  82. I got this for my husband to replace his old, worn out electric razor. He was very pleased with it. So far it has good battery life and a good close shave.
  83. This is the sixth Norelco electric razor that I have used and my observations are: 1) This is a very good basic electric razor. 2) The shave is close and much quieter than the electric razors I have had in the past. At first, I mistakenly felt that since this razor was so quiet that it was not powerful. I was wrong. I get close shaves with this. 3) The instructions say that you should wash/rinse after each use, but I don't feel that's necessary. I rinse mine out after every few days. 4) Again, this is a basic razor. No LED displays, no battery life indicator or minutes left of usage. Only a weak battery indicator. 5) Doesn't come with a stand or case. Again, just basic. 6) Battery life seems fairly good. I have been using this every weekday for about three weeks and I haven't needed to charge this. 7) I like the convenience of simply rinsing under hot water. Simple maintenance. 8) I also like the Aqua-Tec technology where I can use this to shave in the shower, although I don't do that often. Bottom line: Very good electric razor for the price. You get your money's worth. If you want all the bells and whistles, i.e., LED displays, battery life indicators, stands, etc., you'll have to pay more for a higher-end model. If you just want a good basic no-frills razor, go with this one.

According to him, it doesn't give a really close shave if that's what you're looking for and which Philips says that it can do. Shaving along the jawline also takes great effort and trying to get that close shave left his neck irritated.<br /><br />It's water resistant so it can be used in the shower which he tried and said that even with shaving cream it still didn't do a great job of giving a close shave which he likes. The pop-up trimmer is a feature that he did love and it's located on the top of the shaver. With the push of a button you can trim and shape your moustache and sideburns easily. Clean up is also pretty easy, just put it under running water or use the cleaning brush.<br /><br />We're still looking for an electric razor that gives that really close shave just like the disposables. If you're also looking for that this isn't it.

  107. I have tested many electric razors but this is the first electric razor that I have started using regularly. I have yet to find an electric that can shave \\"as close as a blade\\" but this comes very, very close. Unlike every other electric I have tried, the Philips/Norelco PowerTouch doesn't pull or tug the hairs on my face, even during the month-long adjustment period. The battery holds a charge well and recharges quickly. I find it a little difficult to be precise when using the three-head Norelco design but for a full shave it works well. Your standard trimmer/shaper is on the back of the shaver. It seems the trimmer blades move a little slower compared to other electrics and I wish it were easier to clean in between the blades where loose hair gets trapped but it does the job.<br /><br />I tested out the claims of using it in the shower but I think it's of a waste of time, not to mention water, to be standing in the shower with the shaver while the water is running. Perhaps you could use the other hand to soap up a few areas or scrub your scalp but you're most likely going to be pulling and stretching the different areas of your face or feeling for areas you might have missed -- just like you do when you're not shaving in the shower. I gave it the college try and really focused on getting what I thought was a complete shave. Of course the result was a laughable patchy mess of missed spots on my face. Even if I had a mirror in the shower, I wouldn't be able to see myself due to the shower steam. If there is any advantage to using a shaver in the shower, I don't know what it would be.<br /><br />The charging light pulses with a green LED as it is charging and becomes solid once charging is complete. The razor does seem to rinse out nicely in the sink without affecting future shaves. A double sided brush is included if you'd rather brush out the clippings the old fashioned way. I wish a nice, sturdy base was included to place the razor in when finished. It feels solid in my hand, not light and flimsy. Most importantly, it's gentle on the face. Recommended.It feels solid in my hand, not light and flimsy. Most importantly, it's gentle on the face. Recommended.
  108. I have owned many Norelco shavers and have always liked them. I usually buy the cheapest version, but this time I spent a little more to get a better shaver. This shaver always leaves some hairs uncut and I have to go back and shave a second time. I suppose if I shaved every day and used all the recommendations it might be alright. However, I wanted a shaver that gave me a good quick shave without problems and therefore am very disappointed.
  109. I have used several Norelco razors and trimmers through the years. A couple were purchased as specialty razors and a couple of others were added to my collection as advances in technology offered new features. All of the razors and trimmers still work. For the price this is a quality product. While it does not give me as close of a shave as a manual shave with a blade, it is sufficient for day-to-day shaving for a clean cut look. It is just a little more work to navigate the contours on my jaw and neckline.<br /><br />This thing really does hold a charge well and I have no complaints with the battery life. It does have a low battery warning although it is not as high tech as some of the other more expensive razors that let you know exactly how much battery life remains. It has the capability to quick charge to get you by if you have a dead battery and need a quick shave.<br /><br />It has a pop up trimmer for cleaning up mustaches, beards or sideburns; however, I use my other Norelco trimmer for those purposes.<br /><br />It does not have a stand or a case; however, it is portable and lightweight.<br /><br />It is super easy to clean after use and the water resistant nature of the product provides additional shaving and cleaning options.
  110. This is a great electric razor! Shaves smoothly and cleanly with no razor burn at all. You can wash it out under the tap without any damage. I can shave for a couple weeks on a single charge, and then it seems to fully charge in an hour or so. Terrific!
  111. I bought this as a replacement for another Norelco I'd had for at least 5 years. It was still working fine but needed a new shaving head and the battery seemed to be slowly failing. Consequently, I decided it was time for a new razor.<br /><br />This Norelco gives me a close, comfortable shave. It charges quickly and the charge lasts a long time. Also, it is easy to clean since you simply flip open the head and rinse it.<br /><br />I have used Norelco shavers for over 25 years and this is the best one yet. A great buy at Amazon.
  112. feels good in your hand and shaves close like all of my prior Norelco shavers but...I wish it had a stand, I wish I could use it with the charger cord attached, I find the on/off button somewhat difficult to locate (it is black like the rest of the body).   113. My husband had a previous model of the Philips Norelco similar to this one and it needed new heads. We looked online and found they were about $27 at the least expensive vendor on Amazon.com. So, we decided to just purchase a new shaver. We went to a local store and found this exact model for $89 exactly as packaged here! We came home and ordered it from Amazon. We ordered on Saturday afternoon and it arrived on Monday! My husband charged it for a couple hours and it was good to go. He is very pleased with the new Razor and I am pleased with the economical price.
  114. I have used Norelco razors since I started shaving 40 years ago. This is the 4th I have owned (yes, they are built to last). This is hands-down the best Norelco I have yet used. It gets through my moderately heavy beard in about 90 seconds with a larger cutting area surface than my previous models and a better cutter design. It is much quieter than my previous Norelcos, and the ergonomics are very good. It charges much more quickly (about an hour) and has enough capacity for several dozen shaves on one charge. A quick charge for a single shave takes 3 minutes. Although I dry shave, it has the ability to wet shave and can be cleaned quickly under running water. This design does not produce a trace of pulling or irritation.<br /><br />There is no need to get to higher priced models unless you are looking for a pouch and charging stand. This product is highly recommended.

  133. Okay, so I haven't seen too many reviews on shaving foam with this electric shaver. I ended up trying it with my first day of ownership. First of all, lots of hype on this shaver. Not exactly sure why that is because it is just a shaver. I lathered up my face with foam and followed the instructions. It said to pre-wet the shaver with warm water before using with foam. Then use circular motions to cut while regularly rinsing the shaver for a smooth glide. Everything seems to work as expected; however, expect a lot of mess! The shaver had a hard time picking up the hairs on my jawline, so I had to go back over it again. The shave is mediocre at best. It is what I expected from an electric shaver. If a person wants a real close shave, the blade and foam is the best. If you are doing every day shaving, this electric razor is pretty good. Note: I have only owned it for a day. I will try and update everyone after a month of owning it. Update 11/10/2013: So I have owned the shaver for a month. It does really well in the water. Haven't had any issues. Once again, this is an electric shaver, it will not get nearly as close shave as a straight razor or safety razor. But for a quick shave, gets the job done. I also got it down to where it won't make much mess in the sink with a wet shave. I haven't owned it for a year, but people report that is around when it dies. We will see what happens. I did notice, the first couple days, it did cut my skin. But the instructions did say give it 2 weeks. I did this and hasn't cut my skin since. Very happy with it. No irritation. Also, a note to everyone who wants to use the shaver while plugged in: Common sense should tell you this shaver advertises it can be used when wet. Would you really like 120V 20AMP going through your body? People will probably end up trying this. I think that safety feature is smart of Philips frankly. Probably reduces on lawsuits. Anyways, if you aren't sure about electric shavers, this one is cheap enough to give a try. UPDATE 06/13/2015: So after two years of running hot water through it, the back hinge just snapped off because it was plastic. It did a decent job until that happened. If you do end up using this for wet shave with soap, be careful on where you run the hot water, don't run it at the hinge other wise it will weaken the plastic and eventually break like mine. Trying the braun wet/dry shaver that is 50 dollars and the way my hair grows it doesn't do well. Will have to purchase this one again because it gets every single hair, but the shave isn't as close as how the braun cuts, when it does cut the hair.

  146. I have used Norelco electric shavers for over 30 years. I started with one that only had two cutters rather than three. This is the latest one and it works well as did the others. I have found through the years when I have decided to use a safety razor for shaving (too much work) that a better, closer shave comes from the safety razor, not any electric. That being said... the Norelco AT810 is as good as it gets. Though I will probably seldom use it in the shower, it is possible with this razor and it will likely not be hurt by cleaning under the faucet. I like Norelco and recommend the PowerTouch Cordless Razor.
  147. One of the biggest pain points with the electric shavers is with the necks. Foil shavers are somewhat better since you can make a vertical pass on the 2 sides of the neck planes. But with Rotary shavers - Pivot heads are almost a must and should and this shaver does not have a pivot head. Spend a few $s more and go for the norelco AT830: [[ASIN:B006GQYSGE Philips Norelco AT830 PowerTouch Rechargeable Cordless Razor, Gray/Silver/Black]] Overall, I still find the shave quality to be good on this shaver - like all Norelco products and currently using it as a additional shaver in my Gym Bag.

  155. I have always used Gillette razors, and I decided to try an electric shaver, since I will be doing more travelling and I thought this would be quicker and more convenient. I was hesitant to try an electric shaver, because I didn't think they can shave as close as a blade. So here's what I found after using the AT810.<br /><br />In the plus column, it does a decent job, it gets rid of the morning shadow, and it is quick and easy. It's easy to clean, and the pop-out trimmer works well. So it is good for travelling. But is it as good as a blade? No. Even though the morning shadow is gone, when I feel my face, I can feel that it didn't get it all. I tried moving my head, holding it up to tighten the skin, and I held and moved the shaver every which way.<br /><br />So, bottom line is, this shaver will do an adequate job on an average day of getting you out the door quickly without your morning shadow. But if it's date night and you want your face to be 100% baby-smooth, better use a razor.

  205. I like the Norelco razor. The battery lasts about 2 or more weeks on a full charge. The shave is not extremely close. Your skin will feel smooth but you'll still see stubs. Cleaning the unit is very easy. I don't like the mini razor used to trim the sideburns. The mini razor is very weak and is kind of useless. I have used it with shaving gels, dry, and wet. The unit works best when wet. I used to use shaving cream with it but rinsing the unit under hot water doesn't get a deep clean and you'll still have gel residue in the crevices, although it probably won't effect shaving performance. Overall for the price, it's nice.
  206. I have had this now about 5 months. I used an electric razor 20 years ago and didn't like it, so went back to a blade - so this was my second attempt of switching from a blade to electric. I only use it dry, so I am not sure I needed the version that works wet as well, however it does work very well. It holds a charge for a long time - I only plug it in about once or twice a week. I still have the original foils in it, so they seem to last quite well. Its much faster than a blade obviously. I think from a cost standpoint it will also be cheaper than purchasing blades and shaving gel, but I never really kept track so that's just a guess.<br /><br />The shave is not as close as a blade, but still pretty good. I am pretty happy with this, and would recommend this one to anyone thinking of trying (or in my case re-trying) a electric razor.

  212. The AT810, as you might have surmised from its name, is the lesser brother of the AT830. It shares many of the high qualities of the pricier AT830, including solid unibody construction, ability to wet/dry shave and fast charging. However, it doesn't come with a travel case (like the AT830), has just one indicator light for battery charging, and most importantly, its shaving head doesn't pivot. This makes it hard to shave around the neck area; my recommendation is to just pony up the extra $15 and get the AT830, which gives you a better shave around those areas. I prefer a straight razor to the AT810, and the latter also gave me irritable skin post-shave.
  213. *written by the husband* I had gotten another Norelco a while back. I love that one, and it is hard to part with it. I did try this one, though. While it still provides a close shave, I still love the previous one. So I recommend this one to strictly newbies that need an electric.

  231. After blade shaving for over forty years I decided it was time to take another look at electrics. Based on the recommendations of my friends I purchased the Norelco AT810 about six months ago.<br /><br />I've used it exclusively since then and have found it to give me consistently close, comfortable shaves literally approaching a blade shave. I'd definitely recommend this razor to anyone tired of blade shaving<br /><br />Pluses: Gives a close, clean share.<br /> Little to no razor burn<br /> At least three to four shaves (probably more) between battery charges.<br /> Attractive, comfortable grip.<br /> Very easy to clean... just flush with hot tap water.<br /><br />Minuses: No good storage pouch or box to keep it in.<br /><br />Update: After shaving exclusively with my Norelco for nearly eight months I started to notice occasional whisker plucks (ouch!) and I wasn't getting the close shave I was becoming acustomed to. I decided to replace the shaving heads, regardless of Norelco's annual replacement recommendation, to see what difference it would make. The difference was stunning. I again get a close clean shave without any plucks. For all practical purposes I have a new razor.

  253. My 84 year old father has used a Norelco as long as I remember. I am 53 and have used a Norelco since I started shaving. My son who is in college now uses a Norelco. They have always been a very good razor and have never had any issues with quality. They have always lasted man y years. I purchased the AT810 a while ago and it suddenly died. Customer support was kind enough to send me a replacement, however it also died. After a week. I just got off the phone with them and since I do not have my original receipt they are not willing to help me. I asked if the unit that they sent me was a refurbished unit or a new one. They said that it was a new one. They are now made in China and after only a couple of years the first one breaks and the replacement breaks after a week. As an engineer this indicates a likely problem with manufacturing quality. To add insult to injury they said that they could offer me a 15% discount from the suggested retail price. Well I thought that I would share my experiences with you, the consumers. The gentleman that I spoke with on the phone was polite and kind, and he checked with a supervisor to see if there was anything that he could do for me. That's when he said that they would extend a 15% discount. That left quite a bad taste in my mouth to say the least. I hate to say that I was a life-long loyal customer, but now I am done. I will very likely never buy another product from this company. I hope that this information was helpful to you and I hope that you have better luck than I have.

  282. I should start by saying I am already a huge Norelco fan. The rotaries just work better for me. I have a Braun as well that I tried some years back, and I almost never use it because it just doesn't work well shaving my face. Tons of spots it seems to not shave no matter how many times I go over them, etc. The rotary hugs the face better and leaves nothing behind. It isn't the same quality shave as a blade, but it is very very close.<br /><br />My major complaint about the Norelco's has been the batteries. They just don't hold their charge very long. And I have had two razors die prematurely because the battery stopped taking a reasonable charge at all and the razor wouldn't work from the outlet. ] kind of get the feeling on this razor that the battery is still a problem, but I cannot prove it yet, so I cannot downgrade it for that.<br /><br />Other than the battery, it works great both wet and dry. Wet is a bit odd though, because it is difficult to see it is working, but it is. I am not sure it does a hugely better job, but it is so much easier on the face. I usually get facial irritation with these, and wet, I get none with this.<br /><br />Overall, Norelco is still the best rotary razor and rotaries are better than foils. And this is a great value. My Braun cost $40 more, and this easily outdoes it.

  287. Right off the bat the full charge light didn't stay lite. I didn't use it, but the motor is woefully underpowered. You can tell just by listening to it. It is very poorly made and isn't as good as the 12 year old Norelco 7885XL,6885XL I'm replacing. This is just part of an epidemic in the manufacturing world that has no pride in quality or workmanship and flooding the marketplace with cheap disposable crap. Products should get better as they are manufactured more, not worse. I have no idea what razor to buy anymore because the Remington I was looking at had the same complaint. I'm sure I'm not the only one who has the same issue of being tired of US companies manufacturing everything in China to the detriment of quality and durability. This razor isn't any better than a Bic lighter.
  288. I was hoping this would be the exact same as my previous Norelco Electric Razor (Which lasted for 15 years!). However, the Pop Up trimmer has been redesigned since the last one I had. This pop up trimmer does not open up far enough, almost at an acute angle to the razor, which means you have to hold it in place to use the trimmer. Otherwise, any pressure applied to the pop up trimmer will cause it to close back flush with the razor. The pop up razor is what I used the most on my last Norelco, so this is an unacceptable flaw in the design in my book. On top of that, the motor used for the blades is very weak, which makes the blades spin at an unacceptable speed. This means that you will need to go over the same spot several times before anything more than stubble is cut.<br /><br />Advise for using this product, shave everyday. Otherwise, go get something else.
  289. I love this razor, it shaves nice and close for that daily dry shave every morning before work. What I love the most about it though, you can shave using shaving cream if you want for a nice smooth irritation free shave.<br /><br />I shave every day before work and it gives me a nice close shave on those days but I usually don't shave all weekend and my facial hair grows fast and it is coarse. Typically when I shave with an electric razor Monday mornings after going 3 days it pulls and tends to irritate my skin especially around my neck. But with this razor I just use a little bit of shaving cream and no pulling, no irritated skin and it comes out baby smooth.

  293. My last Norelco lasted for many years and worked great. This new one is amazingly light and quiet and, gives an even better shave. If it last as long as the last one, will be well worth the money.
  294. I do like Norelco shavers, particularly the wet/dry ones. I don't like to shave dry. Although regular razors give a much closer shave, it takes a long time to get hot water to the bathroom sink, making shaving with a razor and shaving cream impractical. With the Norelco wet/dry shavers, I can shave in the shower, and be done very quickly. I should note that I'm on my third or forth Norelco now. They stopped making blade refill kits for one. The batteries of the others have stopped holding a charge. The batteries are often soldered on to the circuit board inside the shaver, so they are not really user serviceable, and the cost of new battery pack and a repair is really more than the cost of a new shaver, when you consider that the new shaver comes with fresh blades. My latest was the AT810, which worked wonderfully for a year or two, up until it didn't. For a few weeks, I've had a hard time turning it on. I pushed the power button, and it would run for half a second, and then stop. If I pushed the button a dozen or 15 times, it would eventually turn on, and stay on. I thought that maybe the switch was getting worn out or something. It seemed to be accepting a charge, as usual. Today, I went to use it, and it wouldn't turn on at all. The LED was alternating green and orange, as if to indicate that the battery is dead. I plugged it in, to try and charge it back up, and it's still flashing green and orange. I'm pretty sure that the battery is gone. In retrospect, I suppose the problem with turning the shaver on was probably due to the battery not supplying enough power. I would like Norelco shavers a lot more if I could change out the batteries easier, and they weren't so disposable. I also have a hard time believing that the blade refill packs cost $25-30 to produce, when you can buy an entire low-end Norelco shaver kit for that. EDIT, 3/20/14: I replaced the AT810 with an AT410, and last night I started to have the same problem. Push the button, and it runs for a little while, and then stops. As far as I can tell, the battery is charging normally, and is fully charged. I can not get it to run for more than a couple seconds, no matter how many times I press the button. The Norelco shavers seem to be getting progressively less dependable, and now I don't know what to do. Maybe I'll get one of those single-blade safety razors that the Pawn Stars guy is promoting. EDIT, 9/12/14: I bought a single-blade safety razor, and the associated wet-shaving kit. It takes an extra 7 minutes or so to shave, but a 3-piece safety razor is not very likely to die on me again, and $12 worth of blades will last me more than a year. Oh, and the shave is much much much closer.
  295. I am going to try to make this review short.<br />I'm good with a normal razor, but I thought this would save me time and potentially money. After getting it, I used it for a few weeks to let my skin adjust as it said, but sadly, I still had to return it. Here's why:<br />The shaver actually worked very well on my cheek where the skin is all flat and easy to access. It was also effective in the mustache area and on the chin it worked decently. My problem was the jawline and the neck. It simply did not work for me. (I will note my jawline is well defined and can be hard with a normal razor too.) And when I shaved a decent amount of hair, it left my neck with the worst irritation I have ever had.<br />I feel like this may be a good product which just didn't work for me. Regardless, I cannot recommend it.

  353. A couple years back i thought it was &#34;time for a change&#34; and after years with this kind of familiar Norelco 3-head design I instead changed to some straight electric razor instead. When the time was coming to replace the heads (or the razor) I went ahead and figured I'd go back to the Norelco types I had been used to before.<br /><br />Wow, what a difference. It takes my maybe one third to one quarter the time it was taking me to shave with the old electric I had been using. This design catches so much more hair on the first pass it's sad to think of the hours I wasted with the old one.<br /><br />The only reason this doesn't have 5 stars is there is no &#34;base&#34; unit to keep this standing tall when charging- like every other Norelco I ever owned had. Instead the charging cord going directly into the power port- it's not the end of the world but something I didn't even think to look for when deciding which model to purchase.

According to Norelco, the item is still back-ordered and they have no idea when it will in.<br /><br />Initially it seemed to offer a decent shave, but the heads wear out quickly adding to the initial cost.   388. This is my second Norelco. The first one lasted me about 20 years. It was still shaving close w/the original heads, but suddenly died. I prefer a corded shaver as the older batteries were heavy. This unit is very light. The battery lasts a VERY long time. I think I've charged it once in over two months of use. It's quiet, shaves close, & does a great job. Cleaning is also much improved. I only shave dry. I haven't tried the little sideburn clipper.   391. I have been using Norelco razors for more than 50 years. This is a great razor. The reason is that since this unit is waterproof, I can shave in the shower using foam as I would with a blade. It's faster, easier, and will be far less expensive in the long run. I never thought \\"foam\\" and \\"electric razor\\" belonged together in the same sentence, let alone in the same shower, but there is a reason this unit is waterproof! Try it! It feels as close as a blade now, which I have never experienced with an electric razor before. Also, it solves the problem of \\"razor burn\\" and irritated skin.<br /><br />I must admit I was getting tired of buying those expensive packs of Gillette Fusion blades, and they never seemed to last long enough for what they cost, so I always used them longer than I should and half the time was getting a lousy shave anyway.   440. Works well as expected and will be put throughout the test every day and without any doubt that it will or should do it's task well.
  441. Good product. Happy to find it works on all voltage levels when traveling unlike toothbrushes. A bit frustrating when cleaning though. (It takes practice to seat the heads when cleaning.)
  442. I bought it in november, my husband is useing it all the time. It doesnt cut hear so perfectly and it leaves skin a bit red somewhere but its a good product :)

  445. Battery lasts long - It has been one month. Still working on a single charge.<br /><br />The rotor blades are flexible! If you press them at any angle, there's a spring that allow them to dip and therefore change angle. I couldn't feel any difference between this and the next version, AT830.<br /><br />On cons, sometimes it doesn't catch all the beard - and skin may take a few days to get used to it.<br /><br />Wanted to get this for travel, but I've been using it daily and moved away from using razor blades.
  446. i bought it again for my friends and family. It is very good.I had one myself.it's good it's good it's good
  447. I was a blade guy. I wanted to try an electric. I read many reviews on here and settled on this model. I'm glad I did.<br /><br />This is my first experience with an electric shaver over a blade. I can't believe how close this shaves and now I don't get red neck burn anymore. Granted, I'm still learning how to shave with this, but the shave I get is very good. You are supposed to give your face 21 days to adjust to the electric, but my face didn't take that long.<br /><br />It's very convenient to be able to shave at any time you want for that &#34;fresh-shaven&#34; feeling. Practically, you really can't do that with a blade. The battery life on this thing is very long. Also, being able to rinse this off is a plus. Also, this shaver is extremely quiet.<br /><br />If you are looking at shavers to buy, get this one. So far it's a great product.
  448. Nice unit<br />Pros :<br />- quick charging ,<br />- good battery life, (I have been using for over a year now still lasts long - I don't have to charge it for weeks)<br />- waterproof,<br />- comfortable to hold and gives a smooth shave<br />- flip trimmer, which really can be used as a proper trimmer for the beard :D. Because you cant really use a shaver if you have a beard (more than a week un shaved).<br />I have used it many times to trim first - takes some time as its small but works really well.<br />- Sturdy - I accidentally bumped into the door once with my mine blade panel open - it detached from the unit so I though I broke it - but it still fits back in properly with a click<br /><br />Cons :<br />- For a quick Shave will not be 100% effective at all areas - like the the hard to reach areas. For a quick shave I use this and then just use my Mach3 on the areas around the neck to finish.<br />(I also had a foil top shaver as an addon to a trimmer from philips - and that worked well on these areas - but wasn't as smooth on the rest)<br />- Fine hairs get stuck on the inside rubber (under the blades panel at the bottom) - it is not a major concern but it doesn't come off if you just put it under running water.<br /><br />Still nothing to prevent from me giving it a 5 star.

  470. First of all, if you don't want a bunch of details, just scroll down to the IN SUMMARY paragraph at the end!<br />Also- This is a copy of the review I left of the Norelco AT830.<br /><br />I'm a longtime Norelco user, and the AT830 is a winner for me. Although I have a tough beard with hairs growing every which way, I have dealt with sensitive skin ever since I was a teenager. I learned a couple of decades ago that a rotary shaver that's made for use in the shower was my salvation. Thanks to Norelco wet-or-dry razors, I experience far less skin irritation. For me, having a good rotary shaver in the shower is indispensable. I know I'm not the only guy like this, so this is a detailed review for those of you who are considering an 810 or 830 model.<br /><br />I was glad to learn of the new Aquatec models, having used the Norelco 6000 and 7000 series Cool Skin razors for many years. For what it's worth, I tried the last wet/dry model (the 8060X) with the fully exposed shaving heads attached to a single stalk. After using it for a couple of weeks, I found that I couldn't get as close a shave as with my old 7735X model with the weakening battery. Also, the lack of a chamber for the clipped hair was inconvenient, so I returned it and went back to the old one.<br /><br />Upon learning of the newer Aquatec models, a friend (who's also a Norelco wet/dry fan) and I cooked up a plan. He also needed a new shaver thanks to a dying battery, so we both decided to buy a new model at the same time. He bought the slightly less expensive AT810, while I spent the extra 20 bucks for the 830. The only difference between the two is the &#34;Smart Pivot&#34; system on the 830, and I'd read mixed reviews as to whether it really mattered.<br /><br />THE TEST:<br />We each used our razors for one week, cleaned them properly with a good blade wash, then traded razors for a second week trial. We did not compare any notes until after going back to our own new shavers. I not only compared the newmodels to each other, but also compared these shaves to those I got with my 7735X.<br /><br />Oh, and I tried one extra test once we got our original razors back after week two- I took my old 7735 out of retirement for one last shave. Granted, we aren't professional testers, but we tried to stay consistent in our testing. We both shaved just as we always did: in the morning before going to work. Both of us shave in the shower. The highly scientific test was for each of us to see how our shaves held up by 10 pm every night. Before anyone gripes, yes I know that Norelco says you need at least 21 days to try out a new razor. Well, here's what we found when we compared our observations after two weeks and two days. Your mileage may vary, as they say.<br /><br />RESULTS:<br />We both found that the AT830 gave a closer shave. No doubt about that; the pivot system did make a difference, since both models use the same HQ8 shaving heads. To be honest, the difference in closeness was greater for me, but I really do have a tougher beard. But by 10:00 each night, I noticed that I had a scratchier face of stubble using the 810. For me, the extra $20 was worth it. On the other hand, my pal felt that his model was fine for him, and he's keeping it.<br /><br />And how did my revisit with my old 7735X go after two weeks with the new models? It gave me a longer lasting shave than the 810 did, but not quite as long as the 830. If its battery weren't on the way out, I'd keep that one. However, I really like the fact that, unlike the 7000 series, the new models don't require a charging stand. The stand tips over easily and is an extra requirement to haul around when traveling.<br /><br />IN SUMMARY:<br />For those of you who didn't want to read my lengthy explanation, I totally understand! Anyhow, I found that, with my difficult beard, the AT830 was the way to go. I get a noticeably longer lasting shave than with the 810, and it slightly beats even my trusty old 7735X, which until now,no other razor could do. The 810, however, might be OK for anyone with a beard that's not so fussy. Either way, you'll get the closest, most comfortable shave in the shower with a good, low-foam shaving gel. I hope this helps someone who really has wanted to know the difference.
  471. Got it as a gift for my husband and he loves it..as picky as he is about his daily shaving?? i recommend it..
  472. Top quality electric shaver<br />Quick charging<br />May take you time to adjust to especially along neck line<br />Easy to clean with tap water

If it lasts three years I will be happy.

  487. So far, so good! Haven't had any problems.
  488. I had neck and jaw surgery back in January of 2014, and due to some long term nerve damage and uneven scarring, it has been painful to shave with bladed razor or my Braun electric razor. The Norelco being a rotary razor has less vibration than the Braun, and does not scrape across the face like a bladed razor. Initially I was not sure I would like it because it seem to be much slower in speed than a previous Norelco I had owned, but I put it to my face for the test. VERY PLEASED. My first shave was a &#34;dry&#34; shave, no foam or gel (will try that later), and little to no discomfort in the tender areas of my face and neck. Based on that alone - I give this a 5-star rating. I don't expect I'll lower the rating anytime in the near future, but I may update this posting with comments on my first &#34;wet&#34; shave.
  489. I bought this for a friend. He said it arrived with just enough charge to give it a try & it worked fine. H had a fair amount of growth to remove & had no problem.

  491. Product is a good value for the money. Exceeded my expectations. I would recommend this product for a quick have.

  502. not that great. its ok for cheap razor but dosn't shave that well.takes a long time to shave with.needs shave adjustments.
  503. i went to a braun series and did not like it as much as i do the norelco shavers so i came to this at810 love it better on my skin less irritation
  504. I've been using the AT810 for about eight months now. I had originally planned to buy the Norelco PT730, as I had no interest in the AT810's wet shaving capabilities. However, a Black Friday sale made this a better deal, and the one-hour charging time (vs. 8 hours for the 730) made this one worth the slight differences in sale price. And I liked the blue color better.<br /><br />I wanted an electric shaver because chronic pain was affecting my manual dexterity, and conventional shaving was becoming difficult. While this shaver isn't really any easier in that regard, it does cut the total shaving time in half (about 3 minutes vs. 6 minutes) so it helps.<br /><br />The shaver does an adequate job, but I can't say it shaves really close. My face looks OK when finished, but feels (not looks, just feels) like I need to shave again after just a few hours. It works well on my cheeks and neck, especially in that awkward place below the hinge of my jaw. However, it takes quite a few passes from various angles to get the curves of my chin smooth. It also seems to struggle more with grey hairs than with brown ones. I think the grey ones are softer and don't poke into the holes as easily. My first instinct to deal with this was to press harder, but I found that lifting the heads away from my skin and barely touching my face enables the shaver to get the grey hairs more efficiently.<br /><br />Though I really have no need for wet shaving capabilities, I did try it in the shower once. It required some soap to lubricate my wet face, and the results were no better than dry shaving. Wet shaving with an electric shaver really seems pointless to me. After all, once you've taken the time to lather up, you really might as well use a manual razor which by that point is faster anyway, and shaves closer, too.<br /><br />The pop-up trimmer is handy, and works pretty well to thin my mustache, but the blades are so tiny they don't do so well with making a clean lower edge. My Wahl hair trimmer does a better job. Conveniently, however, the pop-up trimmer can deal fairly effectively with most of the longer face hairs that the shaver misses.<br /><br />This shaver's construction is solid enough, and after eight months still feels durable. Clean-up is easy with a quick rinse, but Norelco recommends using hot water which negates any energy savings otherwise gained by shaving with an electric razor. Sometimes I just use cold water if I forget to run the hot water. After about six months the shaver's performance was declining a bit. It just wasn't cutting quite as close. I wondered if the rinsing was depositing minerals from our tap water on the blades. I think my theory was correct, because I started spraying the inside of the heads with a 50/50 mixture of vinegar and water to dissolve minerals, and after a few days the shaver started shaving closer again.<br /><br />Bottom line, I give the shaver 3 stars for overall shaving results (i.e. it's adequate), and 5 stars for quality construction and ease of use.
  505. I have a ten year old Norelco shaver that still does an excellent job shaving, but the battery was loosing efficiency. The AT810 does a good job, but not as efficiently as the old one. It seems to shave better when a shaving gel is used.
  506. I rarely take time to write a review on any item, but this electric shaver is so good I wanted to share my experience. I formerly shaved with a dry electric several times a week and a straight razor several times when I wanted to get a closer shave. I tried several brands of electric shaver with various experiences but none shaved better than my straight razor, until I bought the Phillips Norelco AT810. I was going to buy new heads for my old electric but was attracted to the 45 days free return offer from Norelco.<br />I tried the new electric three different ways: 1. dry shave using Mennon's pre-shave and the results were as good as my straight razor with a little bit of skin burn; 2. I wet my face and the razor with just water and the shave was great with no burn and as good as my straight razor. 3. I wet my face and applied a small amount of shaving cream and the shave was spectacular and better than my straight razor. I have now employed the shaving cream and a little water method for the last three weeks and the shaves are great every day! The Norelco AT810 cleans very easily and the 1hr charge lasts the entire week. This razor actually gets the beard hairs under my nose that my previous electrics could never get and I had trouble cutting with my straight razor.<br /> I suggest you try this razor if you're looking for a really close shave with no skin burn. It comes with a 45 day free return guarantee so you can't lose if you don't like it. I am near the end of the 45 day period but I doubt if I will send this back.

I have zero complaints except that I've had to get used to the fact it's not going to shave as close as my old Norelco or a blade....pretty near close but, you will definitely need a touch up if going out in the evening. For the last 10 years, I used a Braun rechargeable foil shaver. The Braun's battery is still going strong but it costs nearly as much as a new razor to replace the blades and foil.<br /><br />This one took more work and did not shave closer than my old Braun, which was disappointing since it took me a while to decide on this best seller. I've been shaving dry for decades, so I followed its dry shaving directions: washed my face, waited 15 minutes and shaved in a circular motion.   541. This razor replaced a previous Norelco unit that was simply worn out after 8 or 9 years of usage. It shaves as well as any electric razor that I have owned, it charges relatively quickly, and it gives me more than two weeks worth of shaves on a charge. While it does not have the pivoting head assembly of the more expensive Norelco models, my wrist/hand move the razor in a smooth gliding action just fine without the additional cost and complexity of the more expensive models. As to no travel case, I am using the case from a previous unit.

  547. I have had my share of electric razor and I always end up going back to disposable razors. Reason being, electric razor never shave close, the break out your face, cause more razor bumps and the dreaded aftershave lotion that burns like fire after you shave. The Philips Norelco Aquatec is so cool. You can still use your everyday shaving cream which helps gives you a smoother and bump-less shave. You will love this razor. I use the Aquatec like a disposable razor I run hot water over it to clean as I shave. And the beauty of it all, the Norelco razors are good for one year.

  554. For years I used more expensive electric razors from Philips, most recently the Cool Skin from several years ago. When the battery died (they can never be replaced for some reason) I thought I'd go for a lesser model. And frankly, with my heavy beard, this model gives me a better shave DRY than the Cool Skin ever did with all those expensive lotion cartridges (which skyrocketed in price). So for $60 bucks less the $5 coupon I had, I'm pretty happy with this shaver. The battery life is splendid, and cleaning this baby is just as easy as holding it under the water faucet for a minute or so. That's it!<br /><br />Color me tickled.

  561. The Philips Norelco Powertouch with Aquatec is my second Norelco purchase but my forth in use. It performs well: shave is close but not so much as to encourage in-grown hairs, the run time appears as stated in the literature (50 minutes so I get about two weeks so far), handle is comfortable enough, trimmers work fine and washing the head out is much better than the old days of dry brush. Hair removal under the jaw line takes some effort but has with foil razors too. Haven't tried wet shaving with it yet. One bell/whistle I would have liked to have: a small case to protect it in the travel kit in-lieu of the plastic head protector. But that is minor. On cleanup: it does take some time for the water to drain out of it...all the more reason to brush and floss before stowing the razor away. All in all - a great value.

  625. I bought the AT811 (the red Target version of the 810) last year for my son and so far its performance has been great. Unlike my own older Norelco, however it does NOT come with a travel pouch, which is almost a necessity when you travel or it's likely to pop open and get broken or make a mess ( if you haven't cleaned it out). It holds a charge well and does a good job of shaving unless you've got more thisn 2-3 days worth of beard, in which case it will pull out more hair than it cuts. The sideburn trimmer is much better than the one on my older model, but it doesn't have progressive battery indicator lights--just a single light which turns from green to flashing red when you've got a shave or two worth of energy left, which means you get little warning before it dies. A big step backwards in my opinion since you pretty much have to take the charger on trips unless you completely recharge before you leave.<br /><br />Like many other Norelcos (and maybe this is true of rotary razors in general) this model doesn't give you a really close shave--you have to keep going over the same area again and again if you want to feel just skin and no stubble, and there is no adjustable head feature. My son uses the water-wash feature but it has rusted some of the steel parts inside, so I recommend using the little brush and a compressed air can (for cleaning computers) to blow out the heads, and washing it only occasionally (and then blowing out the water so it doesn't rust).<br /><br />All in all, it's a good shaver. I think it's a bit pricey for what it delivers, especially without a travel pouch and progressive battery lights. But it works well.
  626. I had a Norelco cordless shaver of the triple head design for over 15 years and really liked and enjoyed that razor. However I can't express how disappointed I am with this electric razor. If you have more than 1 days stubble this razor is almost useless. The speed at which the blades turn is slow and anemic. It will not operate as a corded razor like the previous Norelco that I loved. This is one product where I feel like I was mislead by the reviews on Amazon. I would not recommend or purchase this razor, try another model or another brand. I feel like I wasted my money on this product!

  674. I ordered this razor primarily to use in the shower to shave my legs and underarms. If you are a woman, you will want to consider that this razor burns sensitive skin. I have tried to use this under my arms twice, but I ended up with red razor burns that ran along the edge of the razor's path.<br /><br />In talking to customer service, I was told that this razor is designed for the face only, and they had no advice about how to use it under the arms. For use on legs, the razor is fine. But bear in mind that if you have soft skin, even with the use of a lubricating shave cream, this will likely burn the skin.
  675. Its what I was looking for. Arrived quick<br />Simple yet gets the job done. I'd purchase again, it was worth it
  676. Nice razor, I like it.
  677. Got this razor last Christmas (2012) and used it for all of 2013. It didn't irritate my skin like a conventional razor, but I always had to &#34;touch up&#34; a few spots when I wanted a really good shave. The bad news is that it stopped working a couple of weeks ago. It's fully charged, but does nothing when I press the power switch. And I had just bought new replacement heads. :(
  678. I was disappointed. I have been buying the Norelco's for perhaps 20 years and this one seems to have a relatively weak motor and doesn't cut fast and doesn't cut close. It works about like my ten year old that Is pretty worn.
  679. I have used Norelco shavers for more than 40 years. I have always liked the shave and comfort I have gotten with these shavers. The AT810 is very easy to use and clean. Just run the heads and the top of the shaver under hot water and it comes out clean.

  681. Lovely, silent, effective, comfortable.
  682. 3.5 stars<br />If you have a very flat face with very sharp features, and straight facial hair, this razor will probably get the job done. My face has none of those features. I have curly hair, lots of bumps, and in the words of a talent agent I know, 'not the most pronounced jaw line hes ever seen.' As such, it took a lot of passes to get the a close shave, resulting in a bit of irritation. Unlike Norelco's more expensive models, this razor doesnt have the contouring/tilting/pivoting of the head to really stick to your face. As such it takes, not only a lot of passes, requires me to hold the razor at odd angles towards my face to get the trimmer over my face. Its not bad compared to some ov the various razors ive used over the use, but there are better out there for a few bucks more. At half the cost it would be 5+ stars, but knowing I can get a razor that worked much better for me for a few bucks more makes it hard to recommend. Also for whatever reasonm mine seems to get very hot warm on the blade covers if I dont periodically wet it while shaving.<br /><br />On the plus side, it works better than some of the more expensive norelcos of yester year, works wet or dry, (your milage will vary with shaving cream as it seems to clog it up--but i recomend running it under the tap periodically if you have sensative skin) and holds a charge for about a week of daily use. Its dead simple to use and has a robust trimmer that works well for those hard to hit nose spots or as a first pass if its been a while since you shaved.

  725. I have been using the Norelco/Philips shavers for many years. They work really well and last very long. Prior to getting this AT810 model, I was using a 7110X model. It runs quieter and charges much quicker. Overall I am very happy with the AT810 model. You cannot go wrong with any Norelco shaver or razor.
  726. The first thing I noticed about this unit is how quiet this shaver actually is. I'd have to say that is what I like the most. I can shave in my office and not bother Gary. And everyone knows you don't want to bother Gary. I tried this unit both dry and in the shower. It did a very good job both ways. I have a bunch of electric shavers and this one held its own next to ones much more expensive. I call this shaver an entry level unit due to the fact that it doesn't come with a case, and the recharge indicator is only a light and not a digital display. With more expensive units you get a case and a countdown display showing how many more minutes of shaving time you get before you need to recharge. I recommend this unit based on the quality you get for the price.<br /><br />Notes:<br />- Entry Level - No case and charge indicator is just a light<br />- Very Quiet! (won't bother Gary)<br />- Very good smooth shave both wet and dry<br />- Very good deal for the price
  727. I have owned several Norelco Electric Razors and this is a Great Razor. Very close comfortable shave, easy to clean with water and is very quiet compaired to my old Norelco razor.
  728. Pros:<br /><br />-cheaper than buying cartridge razors like the Fusion, especially if you shave twice a day<br />-less irritating, once your skin gets used to it<br />-waterproof<br />-light, long lasting battery pack (I charge it once a week)<br />-easy to clean<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />-not as close of a shave as disposable blade razors<br />-hard to get a close shave on angle of jaw and neck<br />-big and bulky and traps water in its nooks and crannies, not the best travel shaver<br />-Planned obsolescence: Battery pack is not user serviceable, once it stops holding a charge, it's scrap. Also with the high cost of replacement heads at half of the cost of a new shaver, it's almost a foregone conclusion you'll be upgrading to a new one in a year or two.<br /><br />In short: read the instructions, take the 20 days (I'd say a month) for your skin to acclimate, and clean the shaving heads regularly.

From the first day, it didn't seem to shave properly and missed alot of facial hair. I read the instruction booklet and went to Philips website to see if I was doing something wrong. It says that you need to allow your facial hair time (21 days) to adjust to the razor. I used the razor for over 30 days and it still missed hair, pulled hair, split the hairs, and cut me once. I tried the razor: dry, in the shower, with lotion/gel. Nothing seemed to make the product worked like it should. I followed the instructions and even making sure the heads were clean and free from debris. A positive I can say is that it does hold a good charge. Maybe I received a lemon, but this is one razor I am not willing to try again.

I get a very close shave and if the razor continues to preform as promised, I will not have to buy a new razor head for another 10 months ($23).

Also give you face a chance to adjust to the razor for first timers. 6 to 8 weeks should do it.

  827. I haven't used an electric shaver in decades and was impressed with the progress. Two things stand out- 1) the ability to shave wet or dry and 2) how quiet it is.<br />After four shaves, no irritation and close shaves. I've been shaving every day and love this electric!
  828. The problem with this razor is it has to be cleaned after each shave which involves taking it apart, cleaning the tiny parts without deforming them, then putting it back together. Without doing so each subsequent shave is poorer in quality. This totally defeats the reason for buying an electric. After two months I dropped a part on the floor that was never found. The the rest of the parts I threw in a drawer and forgot about it. The best most convenient shave is disposables - 10 for a dollar at dollar stores.
  829. This product shaves very well. I like the fact that there is a flip out trimmer to help with sideburns and other hard to reach areas.

  833. This is my first electric razor so I can't quite comment on how it compares to other razors. What I like about this razor is how easy it is compared to a razor blade. No gel, no mess. This is perfect for people who wants things done the simplest way possible. I am very impressed by the closeness of the shave. I get a closer and smoother shave with this versus a razor blade. The thing I did not enjoy about a blade is that you risk cutting yourself if you try to shave to close. But with this, you can shave close AND get away without a cut. I was a bit surprised when I found out the rotary spun slower than I expected, and this is probably the reason why sometimes there is 1 strand of hair that hasn't been shaved. But that just means you have to go over it a couple times, which is no problem at all.<br />Overall I am very satisfied with this, and the popup trimmer is a plus. Also, it's very nice to have the option of shaving under dry or wet conditions.
  834. I bought the AT810 to replace a 7 year old Norelco 6863XL. I liked the previous razor, but I like the AT810 even more. It is quieter, lighter, more comfortable to use, and shaves closer. I am using it dry and got 26 shaves from the first charge of the battery. I look forward to using it every morning.
  835. The most simple, yet the most elegant electric razor for the price. I purchased this electric razor to replace my old Philips Norelco shaver. This is my 3rd consecutive Philips electric shaver, each of which lasted around two years or so before I upgraded to the newest one, so I have been a loyal customer for five or six years. Each one has increased in quality over the years and is still at a great price point when you could spend upwards of $100 to $200 on a high-end electric razor. This one achieves a close shave and has a fantastic battery life, considering I shave every other day, and only have to charge once every couple weeks. I highly recommend this shaver to anyone who shaves often and needs a quality electric razor on a modest budget.

  860. I've been using the Norelco savers for years. I've always purchase the cheaper 700 series model. I have a tough beard and the blades would only last about a year. Seems wasteful but I couldn't justify spending for blades when I could get a new shaver for a few dollars more. Anyway, this time I bought the more expensive model hoping for a closer shave and longer blade life. However, in reading the manual (yes I do read them) Norelco recommends changing the blades once a year...LOL So far I can't really tell any difference in shave quality between the two models. Both give me a close shave. This one is suppose to be water proof. However I use to wash out the 700 series under the faucet with no problems. Time will tell how this 810 holds up.   861. Excellent mid-price electric Norelco razor. Doesn't have the pivoting head of the SensoTouch line but still does a great job. Just need to maneuver it around a little more with your hands. I consider it a must that my electric razor be water proof so that I can use it in the shower or with shaving gel/cream. This one fits the bill and even makes it nice and simple to clean out the blade compartment with a rinse under the sink faucet. The razor DOES NOT come with a case or charging/storage stand (took off a star for not having those). If these things are important to you I would consider paying a little more to move up to one of the SensoTouch razors that do come with a nice travel case and charging/storage stand.
  862. When I charge it, sometimes the green light turns off within one hour. I don't know when it will be completely charged, the green light should be always on during charging, and is off when charging is complete.
  863. I have been a long time user of electric razors primarily because my face is very sensitive. I would love the closeness of a razor blade and having the refreshing feeling you get from using shaving cream. But unfortunately shaving with a razor blade was a bloody mess for me (literally, not the British vernacular). It didn't matter if I used the best razor blade system or whatever kind of shaving cream. I really had no other option than to use an electric razor and this worked fine for me for decades. That is until my latest Norelco bit the dust and I needed to buy a new one. After reading the overall good reviews for the Norelco AT810 Powertouch with Aquatec, I figured I would give it a try even if I wasn't planning on using it with water and shaving cream. I was very pleased with how it shaved dry and would have been very satisfied if that's how I was going to use it. But one day I tried it with shaving cream....WOW!!! It worked great and the end result was getting a razor close shave. No nicks, no cuts, just close! After use, you just open up the lid and rinse out and let air dry. I also like the way the AT810 is whisper quiet. Not that it probably matters much, I used Edge shaving cream. I'm sure you could use pretty much any kind. I could not be happier with this electric razor. Now for our friends across the pond, I suppose it's fair that I should now use the British vernacular...IT'S BLOODY AWESOME!!!
