  870. I've had electric razors before, some rotary and some foil heads, but I've always returned to the blade and foam because it just seemed I would get a much closer shave. Well, I think Norelco really got it right with this model electric shaver. You do have to give it the time it wants to do the job, but I have come to believe it can match the blade for closeness and it doesn't irritate your skin like some electric shavers do. I have to admit that I was kind of skeptical about Norelco's slots and holes in the shaving head. They claim that the holes get closer to cutting off the stubble that the slots leave behind. It sounded like advertising hype to me. Well, Norelco was right. It must be the reason why the Norelco gives you such a close shave. I'm amazed how good it can shave you. It can match the blade for closeness, so I've retired the blade and don't miss it one bit. Good job,Norelco!!

  881. If you shave totally &#34;by eye&#34; and never touch your face to see if you missed any whiskers, this shaver would be wonderful. My first impression was how very quietly it runs, which I do like very much.<br /><br />I started using electric shavers 40 years ago, and have not used a blade since. In fact my first shaver was a Norelco Triple Header very much like this one, albeit a lot heavier and with a cord. Since then I switched to Braun cordless which I used a long time, as I liked its self cleaning feature. From there I went to the Panasonic ES 8249 which I used right up to purchasing this Norelco (and still use, unfortunately). It seems I have a very ornery set of whiskers, that would appear to run and hide as the shaver approaches, then jump back out and laugh after it passes by. I bought this Norelco to see if I could improve upon the frustrating process of shaving this ornery beard, perhaps better than the Panasonic. No way.<br /><br />I shave each and every morning. After spending a nice quiet 10 minutes of going over and over and over my face with this Norelco, I have to pull out my noisy Panasonic and &#34;actually shave&#34;. I really wanted to like this Norelco. But between its serious lack of getting anywhere near as close a shave as the Panasonic, and the fact that its triple head design now feels like trying to shave with something the size of a dinner plate's face, I am not impressed. Despite how frustrating it is to actually accomplish a decent shave with ANY shaver, the Norelco foils have to be several times thicker than the ES8249 uses. One of the nifty things about the Panasonic is that I can hear the high pitched 'tick' as each whisker gets cut. So after having tried with the Norelco and switching to the Panasonic, not only can I feel the closer shave with my fingers as I am getting it, I can hear the Panasonic cutting all the whiskers shorter as it goes over the stubble left behind by the Norelco.<br /><br />In all fairness, my last Norelco Cordless before I bought the Braun did have the Lift and Cut style cutters, and I remember getting a nice smooth and close shave with it. So something has changed, for the much worse, in Norelco's current design. The cutters on this new Norelco, well, &#34;don't cut it&#34; as the saying goes. I plan to give this thing a full week of effort, but at this rate (after the second day) I am inclined to return it. I know they say allow a few weeks for one to get used to the electric shaver, but since that's all I've shaved with for 40 years I doubt I need much getting used to it. And when I did buy this Panasonic a couple years back, after the Braun literally fell apart from age, it instantly shaved as well or even better than it is doing today. No acclimation period was required. So I don't think allowing more time is going to matter.<br /><br />Some Amazon reviewers mention on these new Norelcos they feel the motor is underpowered. I have to say that for what it DOES cut, it seems powerful enough. It just can't cut close to the skin as the design is supposed to do. Maybe they need to study how thin the foils are on other modern shavers and then redesign the Norelco.
  882. This was a Christmas Gift for my husband. His old Norelco was more than 20 yrs old. He LOVES it! Charges fast, and works great.<br />Good product.

  891. I was expecting an improvement over my much less expensive 8 year old corded Norelco. I was concerned that there might be chaffing or a too-close cut of my relatively light beard. Not so.   922.   925. this is my third Norelco shaver and find it to be very comfortable in the hand, gives a good shave and is trouble free
  926. Works great. I have used it in the shower every morning for about a year now, and it's still going strong
  927. Its a razor. It cuts facial hair. I use it in the shower, wet, and with shaving cream. That's right...world's most sensitive face skin. I bought one of these two years ago, used it almost daily in the shower with shaving cream, with no problems. I hadn't even replaced the blades yet and it still shaved well. If I hadn't dropped it on to the marble floor and broken the flip up top thingy, I am sure it'd still be running. Considering that I got 2 years out of it, I didn't feel too bad having to buy a new one. Especially considering how well it works for me.

  931. I got the AT810 to replace my old 8170XL and well ... it is about the same. It provides about the same quality shave, takes about the same amount of time to charge, and it feels about the same in my hand (but a bit fatter). This version will go into the shower without frying itself (or me) but other than that it is about the same beast. So, if you liked or disliked any of the old Philips/Norelco razors you will have the similar impression. It is missing a travel case or a battery charge level indicator (other than a single light) so it is not optimal for traveling but for every day use this is a fine affordable product.
  932. Philips Norelco with a trimmer. I really like it.........and may I add that I AM WOMAN. Yes, we can actually buy razor.....and the trimmer is great for the back of our neck. So yes it works great for MEN too. The razor was well packaged. It arrived FAST and I am happy with the price too.
  933. \\"Phillips Norelco power torch really chargeable cordless razor;\\" is a wonderful electric razor to shave with. I have used Norelco for many years and this cordless Norelco is comparable to all of my previous razors. It has to flip up trimmer on the side to get scraggly hair at the neck or around the ears. The reason I choose Norelco over other razors is due to its reliability and superior blade use. I have tried using other electric razors and they just don't hold up next to a Norelco razor. It is hard to make a review about a product that in my opinion is superior to any other comparable piece of equipment, please take this into advisement as you read this review. I have always used Norelco and shall continue. This razor comes with a very reasonable price. It also runs on very little power compared to past Norelco's. I hope this review is helpful in you making your decision to purchase a product for shaving.
  934. I only give this unit a lower rating because I have had better electric razors in the past for around the same price point. That being said, this unit performs much better than the last one I had... The prior model I reviewed here on amazon yanked and pulled hair out of my face in a manner that was just not cool.<br /><br />This unit hasn't given me any problems at all at this point, I just wish it would do a little better with some of the odd ball hairs on my neck area. I have several stubborn hairs that have always been a challenge for electric razors for me. Even getting at them with clippers proves to be a pain, they seem to lay right along the skin and refuse to get picked up. My old electric razor that died on me year ago did a lot better with these few stubborn hairs, well several.<br /><br />Overall, this has done a pretty good job and will perform pretty well for most people as long as they don't have any crazy weird growth issues like I do.<br /><br />When I have time I much more prefer to shave with my DE Merkur Progress, I do much more prefer the traditional way of shaving but on road trips and days when you wake up late I grab the electric and take care of the beard. It doesn't get nearly as close of a proper shave but it's not bad and is better than a lot of other electrics on the market. While this isn't a top of the line model it's still rather good and should be on the top of anyone's list that is looking for an electric razor, maybe if you bump the amount you want to spend you can get a little more performance but that's a gamble as some of the higher priced models don't perform as they should either.
  935. This razor is great for the price and shaves close. I haven't used the more expensive model that some of the reviews here talk about, but this is about as much as I want to spend. It's so much better than a disposable razor and well worth it, even if you have to spend more time cleaning it.
  936. The Philips Norelco is a excellent dry/wet electric razor. My hubby 's skin is extremely sensitive and this works really well without irritating his skin. Thanks
  937. WOW! technology has sure ramped up since the old razor i got as a handme down from my 80 year old dad. this thing holds a crazy charge (they say 50 hours and i am starting to believe it) allowing me to travel to south america (220 v) and not need to charge for a month! it cuts well but i have to work at it... moving over my face many times and never getting it all (dry shave). but its supremely comfortable and so quiet i no longer have to avoid shaving when my sleeping wife is just several feet away. i would say its quieter than an electric toothbrush. its also fully usable wet or even soaking so far as i can tell although its hard to bring myself to submerge it. cleaning it with water, however, is a cinch. so, although my previous razors were from the stone age (painful, noisy and couldn't hold a charge) this razor is sharp. UPDATE about how long the blades last: After about 6 months of mostly daily use, i noted a reduction in cutting quality. From the amazing initial cuts that would take a minute or so, now i was getting poor quality cuts in both closeness and number of hairs missed. After about nine months, i needed to shave for 15 minutes to get a really lousy cut that missed many hairs and was by no means close elsewhere. I tried sharpening the blades with a fine blade sharpener on my own and it got moderately better but did not last for more than a month or so. Now, about a year after the purchase, i broke down and got new blades online through target (i spent $22 with free shipping and taxes included). With the new blades, I am now getting amazing effortless shaves again. I also got a replacement policy for 4$ that replaces these blades for two years even with only normal wear and tear. we'll see if they honor that in a year... but i specifically told them my scheme (of planned replacement) and they were fine with it. Here's the summary: its a great razor giving great shaves... but after about 6 months, this course stubble of mine (really anormal beard that if i let it grow comes in real soft) beat down those blades to the point of needing replacement. Philips recommends replacement of blades every year and i suspect its closer to every 9 months. So, factor that into your equations.

It take me around 8 minutes to shave each day. This isn't much of an issue though as it takes 1 hour to completely charge.<br /><br />I would recommend this product to anyone as long as the users expectations are to still need that cheap disposable to get what is left behind. If you are wanting to have the do it all electric razor and never need a blade again, this is not the product for you.

  955. Best used on short stubble. Longer whiskers, 1/8&#34; or so, especially if they're softer, tend not to get guided into the cutting head. In that case, you'd be better off using the trimmer blade to cut everything down to a much shorter length, then use the shaver normally to get a clean shave. I get really good results on dry skin, stretched tight. On freshly washed and still moist skin, the shaver drags a bit and requires more time to get a close shave. Overall, it's a firmly competent shaver with excellent battery life.

  961. Years ago, my first experience with an electric razor was not a good one. I remember razor burns and the feeling of hair being pulled. The experience was damaging enough that for the past decade or so I have been using manual razors such as the Mach 3 or Gillette Fusion. Replacing cartridges is painful, and I tried to make them last as long possible stretching their point of usefulness. Recently, I calculated my needs and came to the conclusion that my system of shaving with dull blades or sporting the mountain man look was not working for my present situation.<br /><br />So I shopped and I found the Philips Norelco Powertouch with Aquatec Electric Razor. Here's was I like about it:<br /><br />Inexpensive - good for the wallet<br /><br />Works very well - smooth shave<br /><br />Quiet - unexpected, but nice<br /><br />Easy to clean - Just run it it under the faucet<br /><br />Can use for a wet or dry shave - options<br /><br />Attached trimmer for hacking down the beard - convenient<br /><br />low profile charging cord - great for travel and reduced clutter<br />__________<br /><br />The bottom line is that this Electric Razor successfully changed my mind about E Razors in general. I absolutely love it, and that love came at a very reasonable price. This product offers a lot of value. If you are considering switching from a manual razor, this product will change your world.
  962. I have not used this shaver with water but it does a great job dry. The shave is close and fast. What is really amazing about this shaver is the battery.   963. I have no complaints with this razor. It isn't the super high end model, but I didn't see any need to go with the AT830 which was about $20 more expensive at the time of my purchase. Overall I am satisfied, I can get a quick dry shave if I need to in the morning or late afternoon, although it won't be very close, and wet it is as good as or perhaps closer than a 'safety' razor, at least for my skin and facial hair, with much less irritation. While it did get slightly more comfortable over the first week or so, I should stress that it was never uncomfortable to use this product. I have no experience with a straight razor or any other system, so I can't offer any insight there. The pop-up trimmer is also great for precision, which is obviously lacking with the regular shaving heads, as with every electric shaver ever. The heads take a little effort to pop off, but I suggest you do so regularly for cleaning - while the entire razor /can/ be put under a faucet, that will not properly clean out the heads, and that will cause the blades to dull more quickly, resulting in a less close and more painful shave. Then give it a chance to dry before popping the heads back on.
  964. This unit glides through heavy stubble like a hot knife through butter! I shave in about half the time it took for my previous older Norelco. I haven't used it with shaving jell or cream. I just use it dry or with Lectric Shave if my face feels damp. I highly recommend it!

  1066. First I was very conflicted with whether I should give this 4 or 5 stars.<br /><br />Cons: I have a full beard, and I purchased this razor mainly for the trimmer in the back in order to maintain my beard. My previous phillips of 6 years trimmer broke, and this had the best reviews so I decided to go for it. Never found much about the trimmer in the reviews which is too bad so hopefully this will help someone like me. Essentially the trimmer pops up on the back, and the natural way to use it is to press down on your skin and slide up your skin. However, in the natural holding angle, doing this forces the trimmer to close. So I'm constantly battling against this thing closing when I try to use it! It's very frustrating. If I go the opposite direction ie pull instead of push, there is no issue. However, this is not what feels natural to do.<br /><br />Pros: When you actually get to shaving,it's AMAZING! Like I said previously, I've had an older model for many years. It's hard to express, but just using this one not only gives you a nice shave, which feels great, but the actual act of shaving feels amazing too. They really upgraded how it contours to your face. I have a very large adams apple which has always been a pain to shave, but not with this guy. I was very annoyed with the trimmer issue, but after using this feature, I almost gave it a 5.<br /><br />Conclusion: If you're wanting to really utilize the trimmer maybe look at a different model which doesn't close on you. If you're wanting to use the 3 spinning razors primarily, this is amazing.

  1090. I have always used a vibrating razor supplemented with a conventional wet shave maybe once a week. The Phillips rotating cutter mechanism was therefore new - to me. I was immediately taken with its quiet whir as opposed to the aggressive buzz of my old reciprocating unit, as well as the ability of the head to conform to my facial contours. But the real surprise was its energy efficiency. My old razor battery held its charge only for three or four days; the new one lasts at least three weeks. (Both are charged via a plug-in cord.) Further, the Philips gives a clearly better shave: much faster, with far fewer little tufts of yesterday's growth left behind. I haven't had the guts to try its wet-shave abilities, as in a shower, but it seems not to mind its daily wash under the tap. It may be rather silly to get all excited about an every-day chore, but I'm actually enjoying it.

I don't normally use shaving cream, but I have used it about once a week and it works great. Use it in the shower, and pre-heat the razor head in hot water before use. Several folks have complained that you cannot run the razor while it is plugged in, but 1) who wants a cord in the shower? 2) It flashed an orange LED when the battery is low so you know when its time to re-charge 3) In an emergency 3 minutes charge will power it enough for a shave.

  1147. I started shaving....well it was many decades ago! Started with a Norelco shaver. Never did seem to give me a really close shave. Over the years have gone back and forth between blade and electric hoping that one day an electric would give me a shave that is close to that of a blade. Must say that my first shave with this razor impressed me. First it was gentle and quiet especially compared to my Remington foil shaver. And while it is not entirely as close a shave as a blade it is very, very close. Alas, I have lost most of the hair on top of head and finally gave up with the comb overs. Between barber trips every two weeks get a bit of stubble on top and neither my blade nor my electric would take that done. But this razor does. Of course to keep it giving me a good shave I will need to replace the head every year or so and that is not cheap. But then neither are razor blades. An electric is so convenient and I am pleased to have finally found one that actually seems to come close to a blade shave. We will see as the months progress and should it decline in performance I will be back to add to this review.

The only difference I found between the two was the fact that the 830 has pivoting heads, and I honestly did not know how that made any difference. It would be bias for me to say this is the best electric shaver ever, since it is my first one, but I am completely satisfied with it. It did not irritate my skin (maybe just a little for 5 minutes but then it was gone, not bad), since it is cordless I could shave while watching TV from my couch, and it was very close to the skin, it gave me the same result I got with the razors. So speaking for myself, if you want to spend 20 more dollars on the 830, go ahead and do it, but I did not and I am glad with that because I used those 20 dollars to buy me a jacket ^_^. I will be updating after a while to se if I got the same results over and over again!
  1166. I've owned 3 Norelco razors, the last one having lasted me 16 years, and technically is still trimming away.<br /><br />The first razor I owned was a hand me down from my father when I was a little shaver. It lasted a year or two before I dropped it into the toilet, which ended it's otherwise faithful life. The replacement, a nearly identical model has served me well for hte last 16 years, but has recently begun shorting out intermittently. Both models were plugins, non-battery models.<br /><br />At one point I also owned a 24$ Remington cordless, which as it were, was also fabulous and honestly gave the best shave I've ever had from a rotary. However, the battery on it lasted just under a year ( you get what you pay for).<br /><br />Anyway, hte battery experience left a bad taste in my mouth so I decided to try the AT810. I didn't realize that it only operated when unplugged. This is unfortunate, but acceptable. I must have read the description for the non-aqua model that DOES allow for corded operation and then bought the wrong one.<br /><br />At any rate, I gather that Norelco doesn't allow this model to be plugged in while operating to avoid electrocution lawsuits. Nanny-state at it's most ridiculous. I don't understand why you can't have the convenience of a water cleanable model paired with a plugin operation. I'm not a moron, I'm not going to plug it in and hop in the shower with it!<br /><br />That said, the heads on this model pivot well and offer very nice contact with the face contours compared to my dated outgoing model. It's a nice improvement in that area. The shave out of the box before the heads have even broken in is also fabulous.<br /><br />So far, this is as expected a very good bang for the buck razor, I just wish Philips/Norelco would provide a model that offered corded operation and water friendly features for those of us who are not morons.
  1167. Great razor! Norelco is the best! I have used them for years<br />but I like this one the best. I hope it last a long time.

  1171. First off I am a dark-skinned black male. This means my facial hair does not behave the way I have seen on the boxes or reviews from other shavers, but this product is awesome! I am hyper-allergic to razors as I found out the hard way over 14 years ago. I just returned the first set of foil screens I ever bought because they did nothing but run over my hair. I had been on a quest lately to find a new way of shaving and not taking as long as I do with some Wahl balding clippers turned teeth first into my skin. Those balding clippers get relatively close but it is time consuming and a little painful, but I have built up a high tolerance over the years. The clippers worked even better with Lectric Shave. Unfortunately because I am graying prematurely, I have to shave at least every other day now and doing it with balding clippers has gotten old quick. This has been going on for at least the last two years. Therefore, I began my quest here on Amazon reading tons of reviews about different shavers. As stated earlier, my first turn with a foil screen shaver was bust. Then I tried this rotary shaver and it was enough to write about.<br /><br />First, I purchased at Wal-Mart tonight but I am a loyal Amazon customer also, so I will save $10 off the Wal-Mart price by ordering a second one here on Amazon that I will keep that second one at my girlfriend's home. In addition to this shaver, I also purchased the Braun Series 3 3500cc just in case this Norelco AT/810 didnt work. The Braun was $140, the AT810 was $70. If the AT810 didn't work then I would try the Braun. If neither worked then I would give up and take both back. Now I am able to take the Braun back without even opening it, that leaves me with a clear conscience. I am saving $70 as well!<br /><br />Now to the experience, I was so overly anxious that I took the shaver right out the box and blister pack and instead of plugging it up, I clicked the power button. It was already partially charged; go fig. They were so quiet and didn't seem to vibrate at all that I figured I would need to plug them up for the time required. However, I ran them across my neck and I heard them cutting the hair! I looked in the mirror and I had a bald spot where they were. Needless to say, I kept cutting. NO BITING!, NO PAIN! All I heard and saw was the hair being cut on my face and neck. It even cut around the Adam's apple. Was this alien technology? I had a little issue with my jawline but being no stranger to a little maneuvering with some hair clippers, I maneuvered this shaver and I got that too. This is the smoothest shave I have had since the unkind incident 14 years ago with a razor. It cut all the hair within 1 to 2 runs in most areas. I am beyond impressed.<br /><br />It is charging now, I am sure I won't need it again until Thursday morning. I am secretly anxious for my facial hair to grow back now because it hasn't had to grow from being this close for over 14 years. I am not that interested in the wet shave because this dry shave, without even using Lectric Shave pre-shave, has gotten so close. Unless I look like I was attacked by stinging insects tomorrow under my neck, I think me and this product will work out great.<br /><br />[[ASIN:B006GQYSC8 Philips Norelco Powertouch with Aquatec Electric Razor AT810/41]]

IN TOTAL, BEFORE THESE GO AWAY WITH THE NEW ONES TWICE THE PRICE, I'LL BUY A SECOND ONE (ON EBAY) AND STORE IT AWAY.
  1189. I've always used foil shavers (Braun, Grundig, Remington) when not using blades in the past but I used my Dad's newest Norelco a couple of times and figured I might as well give this one a try. This is a less expensive model than Dad has, but still gets the job done. What I do like about it is that #1 it doesn't try too hard to cut too close, resulting in razor burn and #2 it doesn't get hot like most of the foil shavers I've used. When the foil shavers have gotten warm/hot at the foil is where razor burn was most likely to occur. As for the negatives, these can be avoided by getting a more expensive model. The cutting heads aren't very aggressive and the motor is weak. What this means is that some areas will take several passes. If you want a quicker shave, you'll need to step up to a more expensive model, like one from the SensoTouch line. The one thing I didn't realize when I bought this one was that is not a &#34;cord/cordless&#34; model. I have always bought cord/cordless in the past and would have passed on this one if I'd realized it was cordless only. The problem with cordless only is that #1- when the battery fails you're pretty much screwed since they don't make the batteries user-accessible like the shave heads. Cord/cordless allows you years more service after the battery fails. #2- If/when the shaver seems to get weak or not hold a charge, you're left guessing whether it's the battery or the motor. Cord/cordless models run at the highest possible voltage when you plug them in so you can tell if it's the battery and not be handicapped by a weak battery. Just plug it in. It's a shame it doesn't come with a car adapter, since it would make a good backup/glovebox shaver. For the price, it's not even a bad primary unit as long as you aren't too impatient.
  1190. that's all ,just so so ,just worth the money,for myself,he,share it to all of my friends,that's all.ok!<br />wht not ne?

The blades are pretty sharp and while someone else's review stated that they want the model higher than this for the better pivoting heads, I don't personally have the same issue (but I guess it's the shape of their face?) with this...the fact that it shaves wet, I usually use this in the shower, saving me time from my old routine...shaving first and then showering. I'd recommend this model, ON sale of course as I got it. Not so sure about full price.
  1232. My grandson has a tender face at 14, this was great for him. It was good to be able to order and know that it would arrive on time!

  1237. At first I thought this razor was underpowered because it is SO quiet. It sounded anemic. But it shaves really well, and is especially good at the hard-to-reach spots like under my jaw line and around my adams apple. It doesn't shave quite as close as my last razor (a Braun), but does fine...and my old one left some of the difficult spots unshaved almost every day. The AT810 shaves much more thoroughly and in less time. In retrospect, I probably could've saved some money and gotten the PT730, which appears to be very similar except for the \\"wet shave\\" option (which I never use).<br /><br />I don't think I'd recommend the AT810 for someone with a very heavy beard. I'm not sure it is strong enough, or cuts close enough. But for the average guy, it's great. Just my $.02.
  1238. I have never had such a close comfortable shave. I've used a straight razor for years and thought I would give this a try. I wasn't disappointed. Saves time and gives as close a shave as a blade.

  1244. I bought this because I like to shave for work a lot, but hate to use a blade razor every single day. This Norelco is great if you use it every day because it gives you a very reasonably close shave. However, if you have grown out your facial hair for a few weeks and then use this, it will not give you a 100% shave, there will most likely be a few whiskers here and there that it can't get (but I think this depends on your type of facial hair/skin). Still, even if I don't use this everyday, it's great because I can get my facial here close to a razor shave, then use my blade razor to finish the job, which makes shaving faster and quicker and keeps your blades lasting longer.<br /><br />My first electric shaver was a cheap CVS/Rite Aid Norelco that was around $20-$30 that I bought many years ago, and at the very least I can say this a huge step up, and convenient too being able to rinse it in water. But if you don't use it every day you'll never get a shave as close as a blade-razor. I'd still recommend it though.

I opened it and removed the blades and noticed that some of my hair ( I have long hair) had gotten caught and wrapped around between the blade and the screen, effectively preventing the blades from reaching my face. I removed the hair and it once again cut as it did the first day I got it.

  1309. the razor is all that was advertised and the price was great, I gave it as a gift for a first time shaver and he was happy
  1310. Updated review: My only initial concern when I purchased the razor was that it would not work when it was plugged in, so when the battery goes bad the razor is trash. Well I am happy to report that so far the battery shows no signs of deterioration, and it's been a year and a half since purchase. I would still highly recommend this razor.<br />Initial Review:<br />I love the feel of the grip and the look of this razor. The cut...well it takes a bit of getting used to. The instruction says it takes 21 days for your skin to get used to the razor and your razor to get used to your skin. If it doesn't happen they say they will take it back, I've had mine a week so far and have begun shaving at night so the razor burns have 8 to 10 hours to calm down before I go out in public. Don't get me wrong, it's not too bad and my lower neck has always been prone to redness from shaving. But so far it feels like it will take the whole 21 days or darn close for me to adjust. So if you buy it be prepared for the break in period. UPDATE: The 21 day break in period is over and as advertised the razor is no longer rough on my skin. I do believe however that the break in period is less about skin getting used to the way the new razor cuts, and more about the razor blades becoming broken in and less abrasive. Either way the result is the same, the razor is working great!<br /><br />On the plus side: It feels like it cuts really nice and close, and you can feel the blades conforming to your face, so it is as advertised. It's very quiet. It also seems to be a lot more gentle on your face if you shave everyday. I'm a bit lazy so sometimes I'm cutting 2 to 3 days worth of hair and that probably won't work with this little piece of equipment.<br /><br />On the negative side: It seems like you have to rinse it to clean it and I am used to just being able to shake the razor clean daily and a thorough brush clean weekly. Not this one. The hair seems to want to cling to the inside. I don't know but running my hard Florida water over the blades a few times a week seems like a recipe for disaster, what with the blades being $30 to $40. Another thing I don't like it is won't run when plugged in. I didn't know they made them like that. My last shaver ran cordless and plugged in so when the batteries gave out, as they always do, I used it for a couple more years as a plugin. Won't be possible with this, when the battery dies, it's useless.<br /><br />Overall so far the razor seems to perform as it claims, gives a nice close cut, cuts the hair instead of ripping it out, and is nice and quiet. So I give it 4 stars. On star off for not being easy to clean, and the 21 day break in period.
  1311. My husband had a Phillips Norelco shaver that died that he loved. So we bought a bit better one this time and hopefully he will be loving it for quite a few years.   1429. I'm always in search of the perfect shave. I've tried just about every traditional blade system out there, and have a foil Panasonic shaver as well but nothing could ever give me the close shave I could get with a Norelco. The one draw back of my previous Norelco's is that the shave it gave me was so close it always use to tear up my skin under my neck so I could never use it. I decided to on a whim pick this up because of the Aquatec feature so I could use shaving gel to helpfully reduce the horrible gashing my 580XL would give me on my neck. Thankfully it has, and I now have that extremely close shave that I could only get with a Norelco style shaver without having to wrap a towel around my neck for most of the day to stop the bleeding that my old one caused (granted I am exaggerating a little). This really is a vast improvement over all the others I've used and tried.
